lessons.title: VPC Foundations (Subnets, Routing, NAT, Endpoints)
objectives: Apply SGs vs NACLs, reachability checks

p: A VPC spans a region; subnets are AZ-scoped. Public subnets route 0.0.0.0/0 to an IGW; private subnets use a NAT in a public subnet for egress.
Use route tables to control traffic, associate them per subnet.
Gateway Endpoints (S3/DynamoDB) keep traffic private; Interface Endpoints (PrivateLink) expose ENIs for supported services.
Use NAT for outbound internet when contacting public repos or update servers.
Security Groups are stateful (allow rules only); NACLs are stateless (allow/deny).
Reachability Analyzer and VPC Flow Logs help diagnose path issues.

checks.q: Private subnets need to reach S3 privately. Best option?
checks.why: Gateway Endpoint for S3 keeps traffic within AWS backbone without NAT costs.

p: ALB (L7 HTTP/HTTPS/WebSockets), path/host routing; NLB (L4 TCP/UDP/TLS) with static IPs and high performance; GWLB for insertable appliances via GENEVE.
Target types: instance, IP, Lambda (ALB only).
ALB for web apps and advanced routing; NLB for TCP/UDP or static IP; GWLB to run firewalls/IDS inline.

checks.q: Need static IPs and TLS offload for TCP. Which LB?
checks.why: NLB supports static IPs and TLS for TCP/UDP.

p: On-Demand for flexibility; Savings Plans/Reserved for committed usage; Spot for interruption-tolerant workloads; Dedicated Host/Instance for compliance/licensing.
Capacity Reservations keep AZ capacity available.
Target tracking vs step vs scheduled; lifecycle hooks; warm pools; health checks replace bad instances.

checks.q: Steady 24/7 workload for 1 year at lowest price.
checks.why: Savings Plans give significant discounts for committed usage.
